sen.j: 金光 清右衛門（かなみつ せいえもん、寛永15年（1638年） － 宝永7年8月（1710年））は、岡山藩士。
sen.e: Seiemon KANAMITSU (1638 - 1710) was a feudal retainer of Okayama Domain.
Seiemon KANAMITSU (1638 - 1710) was a feudal retainer of the Okayama clan.
Seiemon KANAMITSU (1638 - 1710) was a feudal retainer of the Okayama clan.

sen.j: 金光安兵衛の子、金光太郎右衛門は祖父、金光宗吉は兄に当たる。
sen.e: He was the son of Yasube KANAMITSU, Tarouemon KANAMITSU was his grandfather, and Sokichi KANAMITSU was his older brother.
He was a son of Yasube KANAMITSU, and Tarouemon KANAMITSU was his grandfather, and Sokichi KANAMITSU was his older brother.

sen.e: He was a son of Yasube KANAMITSU, and Tarouemon KANAMITSU was his grandfather, and Sokichi KANAMITSU was his older brother.

sen.j: 寛文2年（1662年）2月22日に池田光政に仕官し、三十俵三人扶持で山田弥太郎（300石のち350石、徒頭・大目付などを歴任）の組下となる。
sen.e: He started to serve Mitsumasa IKEDA in February 22, 1662 and became kumishita (who serves under powerful military commander) of Yataro Yamada with an annual stipend of thirty bales for three people (three hundred goku [crop yields], later three hundred and fifty goku, holding various posts such as kachigashira [leader of the group walking first place in line and guarding streets for the shogun] and Ometsuke [chief inspector of the Edo shogunate]).

He started to serve Mitsumasa IKEDA on April 10, 1662 and became kumishita (who serves under powerful military commander) of Yataro Yamada with an annual stipend of thirty bales for three people (three hundred koku [crop yields], later three hundred and fifty koku, holding various posts such as kachigashira [leader of the group walking first place in line and guarding streets for the shogun] and Ometsuke [chief inspector of the Edo shogunate]).

sen.e: He started to serve Mitsumasa IKEDA on April 10, 1662 and became kumishita (who serves under powerful military commander) of Yataro Yamada with an annual stipend of thirty bales for three people (three hundred koku [crop yields], later three hundred and fifty koku, holding various posts such as kachigashira [leader of the group walking first place in line and guarding streets for the shogun] and Ometsuke [chief inspector of the Edo shogunate]).

sen.j: 翌寛文3年（1663年）4月1日、江戸御蔵奉行申付となり江戸へ赴任となる。
sen.e: Seiemon took the post of Edo Okura bugyo (the magistrate of storehouse) and moved to Edo in April 1, 1663.
Seiemon took the post of Edo Okura bugyo (the magistrate of storehouse) and moved to Edo on May 8, 1663.

sen.e: Seiemon took the post of Edo Okura bugyo (the magistrate of storehouse) and moved to Edo on May 8, 1663.

sen.j: その後は、各種役目を歴任しつつ国許と江戸を往復する日々が続いた。
sen.e: After that he held various roles while spending days coming and going between Okayama and Edo.
After that, he took various posts while spending days coming and going between his hometown and Edo.
sen.cmt: 役目をpostに、国許をhometoenとし、after thatの後にコンマを加えました。
sen.e: After that, he took various posts while spending days coming and going between his hometown and Edo.

sen.j: 延宝2年（1674年）1月9日、九俵壱人扶持加増。
sen.e: In January 9, 1674, nine bales for one person were added to his stipend.
On February 14, 1674, nine bales for one person were added to his stipend.

sen.e: On February 14, 1674, nine bales for one person were added to his stipend.

sen.j: 同年6月、馬見所厩長屋横目付となる。
sen.e: He became Yokome (job title in samurai family, the job involves watching over officers) in Nagaya (long, row house) of horse kensho (guest seating) stable in June of the same year.
He became Yokome (job title in samurai family, the job involves watching over officers) at the stable of horse kensho (where people can watch horse race and practice) in July of the same year.

On February 28, 1675, he became kurabugyo (the magistrate of storehouse).

sen.j: 延宝3年4月9日、京都大火災によって焼失した京都御所の禁裏作事（再建工事）のため、京都にて石方横目付として御所再建に尽力した。
sen.e: In May 3, 1675, the Kyoto Imperial Palace was burnt down by a Kyoto great fire and Seiemon poured energy to reconstruct the Imperial Palace as Inspector of stone masons for kinri sakuji (reconstruction work) of the Kyoto Imperial Palace.

On April 9, 1675, the Kyoto Imperial Palace was burnt down by a Kyoto great fire and Seiemon poured his energy into the reconstruction of the Imperial Palace as an Inspector of stone masons for kinri sakuji (reconstruction work) of the Imperial Palace in Kyoto.

sen.e: On April 9, 1675, the Kyoto Imperial Palace was burnt down by a Kyoto great fire and Seiemon poured his energy into the reconstruction of the Imperial Palace as an Inspector of stone masons for kinri sakuji (reconstruction work) of the Imperial Palace in Kyoto.

sen.j: 延宝4年（1676年）4月16日から翌延宝5年（1677年）まで京都と江戸を往復する日々が続いた。
sen.e: From April 16, 1676 to 1677, he spent days coming and going between Kyoto and Edo.
From May 28, 1676 to 1677, he spent days coming and going between Kyoto and Edo.

sen.e: From May 28, 1676 to 1677, he spent days coming and going between Kyoto and Edo.

sen.j: 延宝6年（1678年）7月9日、江戸より岡山に帰国。
sen.e: He returned to Okayama from Edo in July 9, 1678.
He returned to Okayama from Edo on August 25, 1678.
sen.cmt: 旧暦を新暦に、日付の前のinをonに変更しました。
sen.e: He returned to Okayama from Edo on August 25, 1678.

sen.j: 7月27日小姓組・さらに禁裏作事の功績により四拾七俵四人扶持に加増。
sen.e: His stipend was increased to that of forty-seven bales for four people by achievements of koshogumi (page corps) and also by the above kinri sakuji.
His stipend was increased to that of forty-seven bales for four people by his achievements of koshogumi (page corps) and also the kinri sakuji on September 12.

sen.j: 延宝7年（1679年）10月3日、銀札（藩札）方御銀奉行となり、天和 (日本)元年（1681年）10月29日まで勤めた。
sen.e: He became a bill (domain bill) finance commissioner in October 3, 1679 and worked until December 8, 1681.

sen.e: It is confirmed that he was in charge of business entertainment for Chosen tsushinshi (Korean emissary) (official business for Chosen [Korean] people) in Ushimado (present Setouchi City) from July 21 to 24 in 1682.

It is confirmed that he was in charge of business entertainment for Chosen tsushinshi (Korean emissary) (official business for Chosen [Korean] people) in Ushimado (present Setouchi City) from August 23 to 26 in 1682.
